'''Iverson Minter''' (March 23, 1932 – February 25, 2012), known as '''"Louisiana Red"''', was an [[African American]] [[blues]] guitarist, harmonica player, and singer, who recorded more than 50 albums. He was best known for his song "[[Sweet Blood Call]]".<ref name="Dead"/>

==Biography==
Born in [[Bessemer, Alabama]],<ref name="Dead"/> Minter lost his parents early in life; his mother died of [[pneumonia]] shortly after his birth, and his father was [[lynching|lynched]] by the [[Ku Klux Klan]] in 1937.<ref name="Wynn">Wynn, Ron [{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p27792|pure_url=yes}} Louisiana Red Biography], allmusic.com, Macrovision Corporation</ref> He was brought up by a series of relatives in various towns and cities. Red recorded for [[Chess Records|Chess]] in 1949, before joining the [[United States Army|Army]]. 
He was initially trained with the 82nd Airborne as a parachutist and he went to Korea in 1951. The 82nd airborne didn't go there as a complete unit, only some of soldiers were dispatched and became rangers in 2nd, 3rd and 7th Infantry Divisions. Red said he was assigned to the 3rd Infantry Division.

After leaving the Army, he spent two years in the late 1950s playing with [[John Lee Hooker]] in [[Detroit]].<ref name="Wynn"/> He recorded for [[Checker Records]] in 1952, billed as Rocky Fuller.<ref name="Russell">{{cite book|first=Tony|last=Russell|year=1997|title=The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray|publisher= Carlton Books Limited|location=Dubai|pages=138–139|isbn=1-85868-255-X}}</ref>

His first [[album]], ''Lowdown Back Porch Blues'', was recorded in [[New York City|New York]] with [[Tommy Tucker (singer)|Tommy Tucker]] and released in 1963, with second album ''Seventh Son'' released later the same year.<ref name="Owens">Owens, Thom "[{{Allmusic|class=album|id=r89406|pure_url=yes}} Lowdown Back Porch Blues (review)]" at allmusic.com, Macrovision Corporation</ref> Louisiana Red released the [[Single (music)|single]] "I'm Too Poor To Die" for the Glover [[record label|label]] in 1964. It peaked at number 117 on the [[United States|US]] ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Billboard Hot 100|Hot 100]], and number 30 on the ''[[Cashbox (magazine)|Cashbox]]'' [[record chart|chart]]. ''Billboard'' did not print a standard [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|R&B]] chart during 1964.

He maintained a busy recording and performing schedule through the 1960s and 1970s, having done sessions for Chess, Checker, Atlas, Glover, [[Roulette Records|Roulette]], L&R and [[Tomato Records|Tomato]] amongst others.<ref name="Wynn"/> In 1983 he won a [[Blues Music Award|W.C. Handy Award]] for Best Traditional Blues Male Artist.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blues.org/bluesmusicawards/pastyears.php4?YearId=23|publisher=[[Blues Music Awards]]|title=Blues Foundation Winners 1983|accessdate=2012-02-22}}</ref><ref name="bnl">[http://www.bnl.gov/bnlweb/pubaf/pr/PR_display.asp?prID=05-83 "Louisiana Red in Concert with Doug 'Harmonica' McLean at Brookhaven Lab", Brookhaven National Laboratory News]</ref> He lived in [[Hanover]], [[Germany]] since 1981.<ref name="os">[http://www.louisiana-red.com/index1.html Official site biography]</ref>

He has also made [[film]] appearances in  ''[[Rockpalast]]'' (1976), ''[[Comeback (film)|Comeback]]'' (1982), ''Ballhaus Barmbek'' (1988), ''Red and Blues'' (2005) and ''Family Meeting'' (2008).<ref>[http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0714603/ IMDb.com]</ref>

In 1994, Louisiana Red fused the blues with the urban Greek music of the [[bouzouki]] player, Stelios Vamvakaris, on the album, ''Blues Meets Rembetika''.<ref name="Russell"/>  He continued to tour, including regular returns to the [[United States|US]],<ref name="bnl"/> until his death. In 2011, Louisiana Red released ''Memphis Mojo'' to broad public acclaim.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bmansbluesreport.com/2011/10/new-release-from-ruf-records-memphis.html|title=Bman's Blues Report: New Release from Ruf Records: ''Memphis Mojo'' – Louisiana Red and Little Victor's Juke Joint|publisher=Bmansbluesreport.com|date=2011-10-03|accessdate=2011-12-30}}</ref>

==Death==
Michael Messer, from Michael Messer Music, noted on February 25, 2012: "I am very sorry to be bringer of such sad news that my dear friend, Louisiana Red, died this morning. He had a stroke on Monday and had been in a coma."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bmansbluesreport.com/2012/02/louisiana-red-has-passed-this-is.html|title=Bman's Blues Report: Louisiana Red has passed. This is confirmed.|publisher=Bmansbluesreport.com|date=2012-02-26|accessdate=2012-02-26}}</ref> Louisiana Red had died in [[Hanover]], [[Germany]], aged 79.<ref name="Dead">[http://www.thedeadrockstarsclub.com/2012.html Thedeadrockstarsclub.com] - accessed 2012-02-28</ref>
